text: May the outward and inward man be at one.
author: Socrates

text: People learn more on their own rather than being force fed.
author: Socrates

text: I cannot teach anybody anything, I can only make them think.
author: Socrates

text: To fear death, my friends, is only to think ourselves wise, without being wise: for it is to think that we know what we do not know. For anything that men can tell, death may be the greatest good that can happen to them: but they fear it as if they knew quite well that it was the greatest of evils.
author: Socrates

text: Education is the kindling of a flame, not the filling of a vessel.
author: Socrates

text: To find yourself, think for yourself.
author: Socrates

text: From the deepest desires often come the deadliest hate.
author: Socrates

text: An unexamined life is not worth living.
author: Socrates

text: Worthless people live only to eat and drink; people of worth eat and drink only to live.
author: Socrates

text: It is a shame for a man to grow old without seeing the beauty and strength of which his body is capable.
author: Socrates

text: Once made equal to man, woman becomes his superior.
author: Socrates

text: He who is not contented with what he has, would not be contented with what he would like to have.
author: Socrates

text: The secret to change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new.
author: Socrates

text: The way to gain a good reputation, is to endeavor to be what you desire to appear.

text: The envious person grows lean with the fatness of their neighbor.
author: Socrates

text: Let him that would move the world first move himself.
author: Socrates

text: Whenever, therefore, people are deceived and form opinions wide of the truth, it is clear that the error has slid into their minds through the medium of certain resemblances to that truth.

text: The hottest love has the coldest end.
author: Socrates

text: No citizen has a right to be an amateur in the matter of physical training what a disgrace it is for a man to grow old without ever seeing the beauty and strength of which his body is capable.

text: He is rich who is content with the least; for contentment is the wealth of nature.

text: Happiness is unrepentant pleasure.

text: The unexamined life is not worth living.

text: Flattery is like friendship in show, but not in fruit
author: Socrates

text: Bad men live that they may eat and drink, whereas good men eat and drink that they may live.

text: False words are not only evil in themselves, but they infect the soul with evil.

text: Get not your friends by bare compliments, but by giving them sensible tokens of your love.

text: The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new.

text: The only good is knowledge and the only evil is ignorance.
author: Socrates

text: The greatest way to live with honor in this world is to be what we pretend to be.
author: Socrates

text: By all means marry; if you get a good wife, you'll become happy; if you get a bad one, you'll become a philosopher.
author: Socrates

text: By all means, marry. If you get a good wife, you'll become happy; if you get a bad one, you'll become a philosopher.
author: Socrates

text: I only know one thing, and that is I know nothing.
author: Socrates

text: Death is one of two things. Either it is annihilation, and the dead have no consciousness of anything; or, as we are told, it is really a change: a migration of the soul from one place to another.
author: Socrates

text: By all means marry; if you get a good wife, you'll be happy. If you get a bad one, you'll become a philosopher.
author: Socrates

text: Marry a good woman, and be happy the rest of your life.

text: It is a shame for a woman to grow old without ever seeing the strength and beauty of which her body is capable.
author: Socrates

text: If a man is proud of his wealth, he should not be praised until it is known how he employs it.
author: Socrates

text: Employ your time in improving yourself by other men's writings so that you shall come easily by what others have labored hard for.
author: Socrates

text: One should eat to live; not live to eat.
author: Socrates

text: My advice to you is to get married. If you find a good wife, you'll be happy; if not, you'll become a philosopher.

text: If at first you don't succeed, avoid skydiving.
author: Socrates

text: One who is injured ought not to return the injury, for on no account can it be right to do an injustice; and it is not right to return an injury, or to do evil to any man, however much we have suffered from him.
author: Socrates

text: The nearest way to glory is to strive to be what you wish to be thought to be.
author: Socrates

text: By all means marry. If you get a good wife, you'll become happy. If you get a bad one, you'll become a philosopher.

text: All thinking begins with wondering
author: Socrates

text: Be slow to fall into friendship; but when thou art in, continue firm and constant.
author: Socrates

text: Strong minds discuss ideas, average minds discuss events, weak minds discuss people.
author: Socrates

text: As to marriage or celibacy, let a man take which course he will, he will be sure to repent.
author: Socrates

text: One should never do wrong in return, nor mistreat any man, no matter how one has been mistreated by him.
author: Socrates

text: Our lives are but specks of dust falling through the fingers of time. Like sands of the hourglass, so are the days of our lives.
author: Socrates

text: All men's souls are immortal, but the souls of the righteous are immortal and divine.
author: Socrates

text: Let us follow the truth whither so ever it leads.
author: Socrates

text: When you want wisdom and insight as badly as you want to breathe, it is then you shall have it.
author: Socrates

text: The greatest flood has the soonest ebb; the sorest tempest the most sudden calm; the hottest love the coldest end; and from the deepest desire oftentimes ensues the deadliest hate.
author: Socrates

text: Ordinary people seem not to realize that those who really apply themselves in the right way to philosophy are directly and of their own accord preparing themselves for dying and death.
author: Socrates

text: When the debate is lost, slander becomes the tool of the loser.
author: Socrates

text: And in knowing that you know nothing, makes you the smartest of all.
author: Socrates

text: Thou shouldst eat to live; not live to eat.
author: Socrates

text: The greatest blessing granted to mankind come by way of madness, which is a divine gift.
author: Socrates

text: Let him that would move the world, first move himself.
author: Socrates

text: The ancient Oracle said that I was the wisest of all the Greeks. It is because I alone, of all the Greeks, know that I know nothing.
author: Socrates

text: Where there is reverence there is fear, but there is not reverence everywhere that there is fear, because fear presumably has a wider extension than reverence.
author: Socrates

text: The heart of the person before you is a mirror. See there your own form.
author: Socrates

text: Wonder is the beginning of all wisdom.
author: Socrates

text: A disorderly mob is no more an army than a heap of building materials is a house.
author: Socrates

text: This is a universe that does not favor the timid.
author: Socrates

text: The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.
author: Socrates

text: Man must rise above the Earth - to the top of the atmosphere and beyond - for only thus will he fully understand the world in which he lives.
author: Socrates

text: The years wrinkle our skin, but lack of enthusiasm wrinkles our soul.
author: Socrates

text: The world's a puzzle; no need to make sense out of it.
author: Socrates

text: If a rich man is proud of his wealth, he should not be praised until it is known how he employs it.
author: Socrates

text: Obscurity is dispelled by augmenting the light of discernment, not by attacking the darkness.

text: Remember, no human condition is ever permanent. Then you will not be overjoyed in good fortune nor too scornful in misfortune.

text: What a disgrace it is for a man to grow old without ever seeing the beauty and strength of which his body is capable.

text: False language, evil in itself, infects the soul with evil.

text: If you would seek health, look first to the spine.

text: There is no possession more valuable than a good and faithful friend.

text: Faith gives us strength and reassurance and leaves us bathed in the wisdom that we are never alone.

text: Wealth does not bring about excellence, but excellence makes wealth and everything else good for men, both individually and collectively.

text: The shortest and surest way to live with honor, is to be in reality that we would appear to be; all human virtues increase and strenghten themselves by the practice and experience of them.
author: Socrates

text: I know nothing except the fact of my ignorance.
author: Socrates

text: Are you not ashamed of caring so much for the making of money and for fame and prestige, when you neither think nor care about wisdom and truth and the improvement of your soul?
author: Socrates

text: The hour of departure has arrived, and we go our separate ways, I to die, and you to live. Which of these two is better only God knows.
author: Socrates

text: The secret of happiness, you see, is not found in seeking more, but in developing the capacity to enjoy less.

text: Nature has given us two ears, two eyes, and but one tongue, to the end that we should hear and see more than we speak.
